comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: Charles Polack was the captain of the SS Kronprinzessin Cecilie. While steaming toward Germany from America carrying some $10,000,000 in gold and $3,400,000 in silver, he received word of the outbreak of war, and headed back to the United States to avoid capture by the British Navy, and was interned at Bar Harbor, Maine. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Kronprinzessin_Cecilie I started a biography of him on Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Polack

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: My guess is that this picture dates from before he was interned, since the pictures are roughly chronological and we haven't really got to WWI yet. Perhaps the best bet is the occasion in March 1914, that Richard Arthur Norton found reported in the Boston Evening Transcript (see his Wikipedia bio at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Polack ). Polack celebrated his hundredth round trip across the Atlantic. Note that he is wearing medals and a bow tie. This was clearly a special occasion. Here's an NYT report from March 15, 1914: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9500E7DC163AE633A...
